This is going to go down as a classic that's for sure. The game's historical and geographical accuracy, depth, replayability etc. can be massively extended by mods. Especially for history buffs I recommend Historical Immersion Project which you can get from the Paradox forum (and my submod, Norse Heritage Overhaul, as well as the "Taxes and Enclosures" and "Call to Arms" tweaks I've made for HIP). I think for many veteran players it is clear that CK3 will struggle to surpass CK2 (especially modded) even in time, due to the different paths it has gone down. It might have a broader appeal, but I see especially some of its features as definite downgrades (e.g. the new way of levying troops, which just summons them to a rally point instead of you having to march them from their county of origin, and the new RP mechanics making people able to "level up" characters to choose perks etc. rather than having characters develop naturally, etc.). Unfortunately CK2 is hampered by its DLC policy, and while the base game is now free, many of its important features are locked behind DLCs: Council mechanics, retinues, trade routes, etc. This (along with the game's relatively steep learning curve) makes it very hard for new players to get into the game. That is unfortunate since the game has a lot to offer. I recommend for people to keep an eye out for sales (or Humble Bundle giveaways) and get the most essential DLCs then. My list of essential DLCs for new players: The Reaper's Due --- (prosperity events and diseases) Conclave --- (council mechanics) Horse Lords --- (trade routes, tributaries, and nomads) Way of Life --- (character focus and events) The Old Gods --- (raiding and pagans) The Republic --- (merchant republics) Legacy of Rome --- (retinues) PS. Not really worth it for the price, but also: Monks and Mystics --- (army orders for allies)

SUNSET INVASION (2012/11) - Adds an fictional invasion of high tech Aztecs who arrive from across the Atlantic to conquer Europe in the late game - This is only for balancing large multiplayer sessions THE REPUBLIC  (2013/01) - Unlocks playable merchant republics THE OLD GODS (2013/05) - You CAN NOT play pagan nations without this! - Unlocks playable pagans (Norse, Slavic, Suomenusko, and Romuva) - Adds a new start date in 867 - Lots of new Viking mechanics! - Revolts are now led by a named leader character - Adventurers - Adds the ability to “reform” a pagan religion - Zoroastrians, and they can restore the old Persian Empire SONS OF ABRAHAM (2013/11) - Adds Judaism as a playable religion - Two new Catholic holy orders - A huge number of new events RAJAS OF INDIA (2014/03) - Unlocks Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain rulers CHARLEMAGNE (2014/10) - A new, even earlier start date of 769 - Story DLC tied to Charlemagne and Karloman - Custom kingdoms WAY OF LIFE (2014/12) - This is important one! - Adds character focuses, such as War, Family, and Theology, that each have many associated events to flesh out the day-to-day life of your character HORSE LORDS (2015/07) - New playstyle for nomadic hordes - Feudal holdings can be razed for pasture land - New succession mechanics - Members of your court and family can now found mercenary bands - Silk Road - Can now force another ruler to become your tributary CONCLAVE (2016/02) - Ruler’s council now plays a much larger role - A new system of favours - Powerful vassals will now be very unhappy if not on the council - Rework of regencies - New system for educating and influencing the traits/stats of young children - Rework of realm laws - Able to change laws defining the status of women THE REAPER’S DUE (2016/08) - Rework of the disease system MONKS AND MYSTICS (2017/03) - Adds secret or not so secret Societies to the game - Characters now have inventories for storing weapons and artefacts JADE DRAGON (2017/11) - Adds China as an off-map power - New Silk Road mechanics - Rally points - Bön and Khurmazta religions (also unlocked if you own The Old Gods) - Taoism religion (also unlocked if you own Rajas of India) HOLY FURY (2018/11) - Features mechanics and bits back-ported from CK3’s design - "Random" and "Shattered" World generation options 𝕮𝖗𝖚𝖘𝖆𝖉𝖊𝖗 𝕶𝖎𝖓𝖌𝖘 2 At its heart, Crusader Kings is a  dynastic order family simulator! - The player takes control of a single individual, a nobleman or noblewoman. and guides them through life. - Gameplay is mainly reacting to events, as well as the actions of other, computer-controlled individuals in the world around them. - The game’s focus on the upper nobility limits playable characters to the ranks of "count" and above, with equivalents in other cultures. Players should be aware of this bias as while the game provides a unique social-cultural angle unseen in other titles, it is largely limited to the feudal ruling elite. - There is no way to "win" the game outside of a player’s own goals , and the player can only "lose" if their character lacks an heir or their last piece of land is taken. - Starting new game as a count, or chief, with only a single province is highly recommended! 𝕱𝖊𝖚𝖉𝖆𝖑 𝕾𝖞𝖘𝖙𝖊𝖒 A province can contain multiple settlements, such as castles, temples, cities, tribes, a nomadic capital, as well as other special holdings. Playable landed titles are: (.Count.) or Chief (County): 1+ provinces. (-Duke-) or High Chief (Duchy): Has few provinces and vassals. (+King+) : Political leader of the country, has multiple duchies at his command. (.-=Emperor=-.) : King of the Kings! It is impossible to play in the role of a peasant, or lesser notables: Baron (castle): Unplayable. The lowest type of feudal lords, with very small meaning. Bishop (temple): Unplayable. The lowest type of clergyman. Bishop's children aren't taken into consideration during succession. Mayor (city): Unplayable. The lowest type of townsman, very small meaning. Capitalism: A comparison of videogame subscription models I love Crusader Kings! They're such fun, exciting, open-ended games that let you define your own story. If we look at the new subscription model we can compare it to other popular models in the industry. For 5$ you get 30-day access to all the game's DLC. So, access to the DLC of a single game. EA Play is 1$ your first month then 5$ after or 30$ a year. You receive access to dozens of games, many of those including some if not all DLC, early access for some games, exclusive rewards and a discount on digital purchases while your subscription is active. The games available rotate. https://www.ea.com/ea-play/games-steam XBOX Gamepass starts at 1$ then 10-15$ a month after and provides access to ~100 games and offers exclusive discounts/deals. The games available rotate. https://www.xbox.com/en-US/xbox-game-pass/games#PCgames Ubisoft+ is 15$ a month and gives you access to ~100 games, many including full DLC/expansions as well as day-one access to many new releases. The games available rotate. https://store.ubi.com/us/ubisoftplus/games/?access=ubisoft Humble Bundle gives you access to ~10-12 games a month for ~100$ a year. This service gives you permanent access to any game provided to you during the subscription period. By design, since you get a permanent bundle of games each month they will always offer new titles every month. https://i.redd.it/v3uulf7hwxf51.png (This isn't conclusive but gives you an idea of some of the games Humble Bundle provides permanently when you subscribe to them) While I love CKII the precedent that could be set by the DLC Subscription service is potentially dangerous. More adoption by other games, pricehikes of currently available services, what if this becomes the ONLY way to play DLC for games? No discount for loyal players that have bought DLC over the years when they could afford to etc.

This game has a notoriously steep learning curve, but if you can make it through a first campaign, this will be one of the most fun games you will ever play. At its core, the game is made up of very simple mechanics that interact in complex ways (think Minecraft, but with people instead of blocks). You can ignore most of those mechanics most of the time and focus on what you want to, or you can chain them together in interesting ways. No two playthroughs could ever be the same. 1,000 hours later, I'm not even close to being done with this game.

Product received for free This game puts you in the role of a ruler of some stature set with the goal to increase your family's status by any means you see fit. Your choices affect how easy or hard that progression is and may ultimately ruin you. You can only lose the game by running out of family, and with that loss the ability to rule. Graphically this game is dull; the entirety of it is basically staring at a map. Occasionally one moves characters or armies around and those entities interact with others with minimal animations. But one doesn't play CK2 for the artwork. One plays CK2 for the stories of these rulers. One also should find joy in experimenting with questionable choices and wild curve balls with the understanding that at any moment it may go horribly wrong. I think I prefer CK2 to Europa Universalis 4. Both are produced by the same company, have similar mechanics and one can cross one's game over into that universe if desired. Thus far EU4 has better co-op play because alliances seem to require family relations and marriages aren't always available. EU4 has a broader world to work with and its DLCs are more compelling in that they substantially change the way the game plays. I don't find that to be the case with CK2. Even so, CK2 is still a better game. Here's why: The stories are better. Plain and simple, attaching my actions to simulated royalty instead of a simulated empire makes the game much more enjoyable. I told my buddy about a play through during which I lost a war, went madly in debt, lost my king, had my child king killed by his aunt (she literally had someone push him out of a boat) and had that aunt - a power hungry nut job - lead the empire into a position of power. That narrative simply cannot be duplicated in EU4. I look forward to trying CK3 at some point but I haven't yet fully explored this title. This title is free to play; there's no expense to try it out. If you want to try guiding power hungry royals to glory while avoiding the wrath of other power hungry royals - perhaps with your friends - download this game.

So, as with typical Paradox Interactive fashion, they do great things and then proceed to shoot their whole foot off afterwards to balance things out.  CK3 is a really good game.   It wasn't released in the same bare boned DLC hell fashion like all their prior releases (Stellaris, EU4, HOI4, and I:R). First, CK2 is the definition of DLC Hell.  All the DLC's added together for an 8 year old game is insanely high.  So, instead of doing the smart thing and lowering the prices or creating a overall bundle that is cheaper than currently buying all the DLC's, they decided on a subscription model.  This does two things: 1) It alienates people who have already bought some of the DLC's but can't afford the rest, so they are getting far less value in this subscription than someone who has never bought a single DLC for this game.  That's terrible, but #2 is far worse... 2)  It shows potential customers that they shouldn't buy Paradox's games & DLC because Paradox could just do a subscription model instead, which is cheaper overall.  That's a death knell to a company's immediate profits. Paradox's greed has hit rank S and is even greater than EA's.  It's sad to see a company fall so far.

I have spent many hours playing Crusader Kings 2. The ability to go from a duke, to count, king and then emperor, makes for a fantastic role playing experience that feels fresh every time I play. However, many elements of the game are flawed, and begin to crumble apart as you start playing. If you decide to play a very long game and you own the Charlemagne DLC, you might be encouraged to play the 769 start date. The problem, however, is that due to a poor AI that is unable to adapt to issues of succession, the map will degrade itself by way of massive kingdoms splitting up into small counts and duchies. If a player does not take an active role in unifying the region, then the map will be a mess for the entirety of the game and the Islamic religion will control all of Western Europe, it’s ridiculous. In between the moments of expanding your realm, there’s nothing to do that isn’t monotonous and repetitive. You can join a secret society, but it’s either missions filled with improving your piety (Religious Orders) or just killing random people of your own society (Satanic Order). Speaking of the Satanic Order, the initiation ceremony is always the same, and you’re either asked to desecrate a local temple or kill some random member of the society, because for some reason you apparently hate them. Once your character, who is a member of a secret society, dies, than there’s no point in doing it again because you’ve already seen it all. You may also interact with your vassals, but it’s such an archaic system that forces the player to do nothing but to click boxes, and hope that the AI will like you enough not to start a civil war. And if there is a civil war, it’s always about implementing Gavelkind succession, meaning that there never seems to be much reasoning behind the civil wars in the first place, other than forcing the player to interact with their vassals. The game also puts penalties if you go over the vassal and demense limits, but there are so many layers piled on top of one another that you can’t give certain lands to particular characters, and you’re forced to have heavy penalties as a result; this can become exceedingly worse once you gain the title of emperor. You may also get notifications that character x wants to kill character y, but at the end of the day it becomes a question of “Why should I care?”. There is no reason to interact with neighbours unless they are looking to invade you, or vice versa. You will get constant stupid proposals for non-agression pacts from leaders located halfway across the map, and alliances are extremely rare due to the AI’s reluctance. The Coronation Ceremony is just a gimmick that gives very little positive opinion to your character, and there’s no point in interacting with the Pope unless you are interested in starting a crusade. And considering how weak the Catholic religion is in earlier starting dates, it’s possible that you’ll never have enough combined strength to begin the crusade, which means that one of the most interesting parts of the game is already wasted. There will be diseases that pop up throughout the map during the game, but all it means is that you have to “close gates” every 5 minutes and wait it out. Even then, if you have a level 4 hospital in your capital, you never have to worry about disease because it’s so easy to cheese the system. The legendary Black Plague as well can easily be circumvented by just “closing the gates”, there’s no level of urgency. There are no differences between characters in the Indian subcontinent and those in the British Isles, and it’s the same events with just different flavour text. You can make the argument that the Mongols and Chinese make the Eastern part of the map more interesting, but the truth is that both of these empires go through the “blob treatment”, and therefore collapse after 10 years of in-game time. The game’s appeal is that it gives the player the option to create their own story, but what this means is that there’s no late game goal. Want to create an empire? Congrats, you did it! You might as well quit the game now, because there’s nothing left to do. And that summarizes the game in its entirety, you achieved the highest rank possible, and now you have absolutely nothing left to do. The voyage to the top was filled with nothing but clicking boxes and hoping for the best.

Product received for free I'm new-ish to grand strategy games and even 4X, starting with Stellaris and Civ 3 before expanding into others (Endless Space, Age of Wonders, EU and some other Paradox games, etc). As such, while I've come to grasp 4X almost entirely, grand strategy still typically overwhelms me for some reason. I'm still rather terrible at EU, Imperator: Rome and the others but Crusader Kings is one series of grand strategy that gripped me almost immediately (though I'm still not good at it). This is probably because, as a huge RPG nerd, I love when RPG freedom is intertwined with other games. Crusader Kings 2 is as much of a large-scale political RPG as it is a grand strategy title. You get to take on the role of the leader of your territory (whether a lesser noble or a high king) and make decisions for your kingdom. Where other grand strategy games typically put you in a sort of "overseer" role (seeing everything from your perspective), CK2 puts you in the shoes of a ruler and you are the one who chooses how they behave. What this does is that it creates a special bond between the player and their territory. I've heard Europa Universalis compared to a computerized version of RISK and I don't disagree because that shows the difference between EU and CK. CK is a strategic RPG while EU is a highly advanced, computerized board game. Don't take that as me dissing on EU, though, as it's a great game too. The reason I said that is because of how different the two games are. You still manage the affairs of your kingdom but ultimately, your character and your dynasty are the most important parts of this game. The goal isn't necessarily to make sure you're some political, economic and/or military superpower. The goal is to ensure you have a strong, prestigious dynasty and to do that, you need to be strategic in how you manage your kingdom and your court. This means that you have the opportunity to choose how your character interacts with other characters. It's a medieval political sim in many ways. If you're not careful, you can make enemies with the Pope or powerful monarchs across Europe. You can screw up your dynasty by inbreeding (accidental or intentional). You can choose to be an isolated state that minds its own business or you can butt into everyone else's affairs. The choice is entirely yours. That's what really makes CK appeal to me: it's a medieval strategy sandbox. You set your own goals, you choose how your dynasty interacts with other nations, dynasties and factions. If you don't take care to keep your vassals pleased, you lose power and may even lose your throne, but keeping them pleased may make members of your family or other dynasties angry with you. If you strategically appoint officials in your court and are tactful in your interactions with others, you will have a much smoother experience; as in real life, you cannot do it all on your own, even if you try (and you certainly CAN try). While DLCs and expansions add loads of other features, the base game is still a lot of fun; I don't have any of the expansions yet I still find this game to be a blast; it's one of those games where I lose hours before I realize that I've been playing obsessively. If not for the fact that I have a billion other games I'm trying to finish, I would have absolutely sunk hundreds of hours into this game. The main reason I haven't is because I know how easy it is to end up addicted to it and I don't have the time for yet another addiction! So yes, even if this game were still paid, I'd recommend it. However, since it's free, you have absolutely nothing to lose but some time and when you do lose that time, you won't regret it. CK3 improves on just about every aspect of this game but given its relatively hefty price tag, this game is a great way to at least get the general feel for the franchise. If you enjoy this, you'll almost certainly enjoy 3 but that's not to say CK2 isn't still worth playing, because it is. The sheer amount of expansions to buy can be very overwhelming but like I said, I don't have any of them and I don't feel like I'm playing an unfinished game. Just play it. If you like RPGs and/or grand strategy (or 4X), this is a beautiful blend of those genres and it's a total blast to play. Live out your fantasy to be a medieval king in a game that gives you the freedom to act like one!

As my time invested would show, I rather enjoy this game, and as a side note, its sequel is rather promising to me. A niche genre for some, but if you enjoy the genre, you'll probably like the game. I played the game for somewhere around 500-700 hours before seriously investing in the DLC, mostly in the AGOT (A Game Of Thrones) mod, so while the DLC provide a lot of content, mods can more than make up the difference if you don't want to shell out a rather hefty sum. My advice is if you are on the fence about it, the base game and mods are completely free. If you enjoy the game in its free form, you can consider if you want to pay for the DLC features, of which there are quite a lot, and subsequently the price tag for the full game is rather high, around $200-300, depending on if you get package deals or sales; prices can vary. If you just want to get a taste of the DLC features, the subscription feature seems nice, if you just want a taste of it. If you pay for more than just a few months though, you start having to pay a lot more than if you just bought a few DLC outright. For example, if you pay for the subscription for just over 5 years, roughly 62 months, you will have paid as much in the subscription as if you paid for all DLCs, but once that month runs out, you once again have nothing. That being said, if you want to play the full experience for just a couple of months, or only occasionally, or want to try the full features before investing $300, the DLC subscription is a great deal. Full disclosure, I have paid for all major content DLC, and you can see my total hours played. You can really get a lot of enjoyment for the price tag, I personally think that the amount I paid is worth it, as of the time of writing it, the game has cost me roughly $0.14 per hour played, which is a better deal than a lot of other entertainment options, but once again, you have to really like the genre to invest that amount of time in a game, so it's not the best option for people who don't love the genre to invest heavily into the game.

Paradox hit a high note with this series that has yet to be surpassed CK2 is an engaging look at medieval life from England to India, that dynamically shifts as the world changes and grows around you. Your job is to keep your family line going, and when you no longer have a heir or family member to play as its game over. Esentially staving off death and making babies is the obvious goal, but behind that is what makes this game great. CK2 manages to chokehold the RPG formula far better than Paradox's other games have since, resulting in some of the most memorable stories you may have in a game. The complexity of CK2's environment and the npc's clashing leads to limitless hours of possible content, or a 10 minute game where your character went out boar hunting, stubbed his toe, and died from dysentery. Anything is on the table and anything will inevitably happen. That being said, CK2 is still a fairly easy game to get into and most of the tutorial is simply playing it and finding out what each button does, despite the very overwhelming UI. The DLC altogether can be a bit expensive outside of sales, so I'd recommend getting a key elsewhere or on the subscription service thingy. All-in-all a gem of a game.

In reality, I probably have around three times the amount of current hours (526) due to playing the game in offline mode at times, and also because I had a "free" version before, heh. Rating: 7/10 CK2 is a great game. It's not perfect, but it has a wealth of content and much like most Paradox grand strategy games, great replayability. It focuses more on building your own dynasty and fame for yourself, rather than simply bulding the biggest empire - although that is certainly a valid way to go about it. Unfortunately, it is a bit limited in the roleplaying aspect by a rather limited interactions system, and by over-reliance on randomized events. While it is a lot of fun, at times, you feel like playing a slot-machine - and you, of course, lose more often than win. Considering the rest of the game suffered from this focus on interaction and events and is therefore a bit more simplistic than the other Paradox GS type games, it can be a bit shallow and frustrating to deal with at times. Still, it is a great window into the life of a medieval ruler, and if you like this type of games, you will easily sink hundreds of hours into it, and it is still one of the best games to roleplay in Multiplayer, where the game really shines, as you can get an actual conversation with your adversaries and allies instead of the limited interactions menu. However, even in singleplayer, the game can still be a lot of fun. The graphics are passable, given the age of the game, and the genre. Music is pretty good, ambience is as well, but some of it will become annoying pretty quickly and the ability to manage sound types and volumes is a bit limited, the game could use expanded options for audio instead of the very simple ones it has. Also, I would recommend getting at least the DLCs that expand the roleplaying aspects, such as Conclave, but I cannot recommend the game and DLCs at full price - if you are interested, definitely wait for a discount campaign, they happen often enough.

I don't have the most hours thrown into this game compared to many players, but by my own standard I certainly have a lot. I wish I could tell many stories about this beauty of a game, but for the sake of time I'll tell one in the world of Elder Kings (a fantastic Elder Scrolls mod). I was but an orc boy in a small county to the north west (High Rock for you nerds). My father had died the previous year, a great warrior finally bested in a duel by a rival he had tormented over the years, his enemies took no chances to keep the great man alive. This boy the warrior's son grew in his fathers name. The boy had a mentor, age 65, the same as the one who had once taught his father. He trained and practiced, till one day he grew strong enough to rule, his mentor stood down as regent and sent forth a new era. Once a boy and now a man, he slay the traitor who murdered his father, killed the past, and took his place in the sun. Bolstering his ranks he challenged the might of the Kingdom of Daggerfall in battle, with crushing blows to the enemies flanks he made many sacrifices to the cruel gods that day. Battle after battle and war after war he conquered his enemies, until one day he had achieved his goal, he had conquered all of High Rock and ushered in the Kingdom of Orisinium, a new homeland for all orc-kin. And thus continued his bloodline following his legacy and orsimer tradition each son would challenge his father to combat, the winner would rule and the loser would die. And then the crazy CK2 stuff happened. One son who was quite weak killed his father who was a near indomitable force. That son then ruled and all was well for some 20 years, until he was murdered in cold blood by an assassin. Thus his son took the throne, but that son was quite weak and had no chance either, he too was assassinated. Then the next son, only three years of age, he made it but 6 months before he was assassinated as well. That son's Great-Uncle then ruled Orisinium who was promptly killed in combat. At this point the Orisinium vassals were not very content with the state of affairs at which point they removed by bloodline from the throne and placed a more stable one upon the throne. And thus my great bloodline were but mere dukes and it took many hours of gameplay before I was able to reinstate myself as the true rulers of Ork-Kin. I liked it.
